metadata.project: IBR Seismic Isolation Study — Interstate Bridge Replacement Program
metadata.description: Comprehensive seismic performance comparison of 3 bridge alternatives for I-5 Columbia River crossing
codes: AASHTO Guide Specifications for Seismic Isolation Design, 4th Ed.
AASHTO LRFD Seismic Bridge Design, 2nd Ed.

baseShearReduction.description: Percent reduction in substructure force demand (column/tower forces) compared to Alt A ductile design

calculation.note: Column/tower force demand at DBE level. For isolated bridges, bearing friction generates base shear but column forces are limited by bearing's characteristic strength

peakDrift.description: Peak column/tower drift ratio at DBE demand level

driftReduction.description: Percent reduction in peak column/tower drift ratio compared to Alt A

altB.note: D/C ratio well below 1.0 at both DBE and MCE — adequate bearing capacity

altC.note: Slightly higher demand due to longer period and heavier deck; still well within capacity

hingeCount.description: Number of plastic hinges formed at DBE demand level

details.altA: 4 plastic hinges: top and bottom of both pier columns (double-curvature mechanism)
details.altB: No plastic hinges — columns remain fully elastic (force D/C = 0.12)
details.altC: No plastic hinges — tower legs remain fully elastic (force D/C = 0.14)

performanceLevel.description: Seismic performance level per AASHTO/ASCE criteria at DBE demand

details.altA: Plastic hinges form in columns with ductility demand of 2.72; controlled inelastic response per SDC D requirements. Post-earthquake inspection and potential repair required.
details.altB: No structural damage. Bearings re-center after earthquake. Bridge operational immediately after event. Isolation system may need inspection but structure is undamaged.
details.altC: No structural damage. Bearings re-center, cables remain elastic. Bridge operational immediately. Enhanced performance due to cable system redundancy.

MCE_performance.altA_detail: At MCE (1.5x DBE), ductility demand reaches 4.09; approaching column rotation limits
MCE_performance.altB_detail: Bearing D/C = 0.61 at MCE; columns still elastic
MCE_performance.altC_detail: Bearing D/C = 0.64 at MCE; tower legs still elastic

altB.note: Moderate period shift; bridge already relatively flexible

altC.note: Large period shift; extradosed towers are inherently stiff

lambdaBounds.description: Upper and lower bound analysis per ASCE 7-22 Section 17.2.8.4 — lambda property modification factors

lambdaFactors.basis: ASCE 7-22 Table 17.2-1: aging (1.1), contamination (1.1), temperature (1.2), travel/wear (1.0) — combined max = 1.8; min accounts for fresh/clean conditions = 0.85

lower.note: Lower friction → longer period → larger displacement → lower base shear

upper.note: Higher friction → shorter period → smaller displacement → higher base shear

envelope.note: Lower bound governs displacement; upper bound governs forces
Lower bound governs displacement; upper bound governs forces

spectralAnalysis.description: Design spectrum ordinates at key periods

spectralOrdinate_altB.note: Sa = SD1/T = 0.6/2.536, further reduced by BL

spectralOrdinate_altC.note: Sa = SD1/T = 0.6/2.905, further reduced by BL

costBenefitIndicators.description: Qualitative and semi-quantitative indicators for lifecycle cost comparison

initialConstructionCost.note: Alt B adds bearings but reduces column reinforcement. Alt C adds towers, cables, and bearings but eliminates one in-water pier.

postEarthquakeRepairCost_DBE.altA: High — column repairs, potential closure 6-12 months
postEarthquakeRepairCost_DBE.altB: Minimal — bearing inspection only, operational within days
postEarthquakeRepairCost_DBE.altC: Minimal — bearing inspection only, operational within days

postEarthquakeRepairCost_MCE.altA: Very High — possible reconstruction, closure 12-24 months
postEarthquakeRepairCost_MCE.altB: Low — bearing replacement if needed, operational within weeks
postEarthquakeRepairCost_MCE.altC: Low — bearing replacement if needed, operational within weeks

resilienceScore.altA: Moderate — Life Safety but extended downtime
resilienceScore.altC: Highest — Immediate Occupancy, minimal downtime, structural redundancy

environmentalImpact.altA: Standard — 2 in-water piers with pile foundations
environmentalImpact.altC: Reduced — single main span over channel, reduced in-water construction

keyFindings: Both isolated alternatives (B and C) achieve Immediate Occupancy performance at both DBE and MCE levels, compared to Life Safety (DBE) and Collapse Prevention (MCE) for the conventional ductile design.
Substructure force demand is reduced by 66-72% with seismic isolation, enabling elastic column/tower design and eliminating the need for plastic hinge detailing.
Column drift ratios are reduced by 98%+ — from 1.48% (ductile) to 0.02-0.03% (isolated). This virtually eliminates post-earthquake structural damage.
TFP bearing displacement demands are well within capacity (D/C = 0.34-0.36 at DBE, 0.61-0.64 at MCE), providing substantial reserve for beyond-design-basis events.
Upper/lower bound lambda analysis shows bearing D/C ratios remain below 0.41 even at the most demanding property combination, confirming robust isolation design.
The extradosed alternative (Alt C) provides the highest performance with a 3.57x period shift ratio, 72% base shear reduction, and additional structural redundancy from the cable system.
For a critical lifeline structure like the IBR, the ~8-12% cost premium for seismic isolation (Alt B) provides a compelling return through near-elimination of earthquake damage and downtime.
The extradosed option (Alt C) has a higher initial cost premium (~22-30%) but offers reduced environmental impact (fewer in-water piers) and the highest seismic resilience.
